MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters. This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn. Provide your answer with these fields. - is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false), - scenario: a specific violation scenario. Here is the code of dir_reader: ```c static ssize_t dir_reader (void *cls, uint64_t pos, char *buf, size_t max) { DIR *dir = cls; struct dirent *e; int res; if (max < 512) return 0; (void) pos; /* 'pos' is ignored as function return next one single entry per call. */ do { e = readdir (dir); if (e == NULL) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM; } while (e->d_name[0] == '.'); res = snprintf (buf, max, "%s
", e->d_name, e->d_name); if (0 >= res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; if (max < (size_t) res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; return (ssize_t) res; } ``` Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze: ```c res = snprintf (buf, max, "%s
", e->d_name, e->d_name); ``` Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
scenario: No violation: snprintf is not one of the <string.h> functions covered by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17, and snprintf itself will not write beyond buf because it is given the size (max). Additionally, e->d_name as returned by readdir is a NUL-terminated string on POSIX systems, so snprintf will only read up to that terminator. (A hypothetical violation could occur on a non‑conforming implementation where e->d_name is not NUL‑terminated — then reading with %s could access beyond the object bounds.)
